title: How to Make a Lantern for the Holidays

steps.headline: Buy a decorative, glass-paneled lantern from the store.
steps.description: Craft stores have a huge variety in their candle, home décor, and seasonal section. You can also find them in some home improvement stores as well. Choose a shape and material that appeals to you. Lanterns with metal frames are the most popular, but you can get ones with wooden frames too. Most lanterns have four panels, but you can get lanterns with five or six panels. Don't worry too much about the color; you can always repaint it. Instead, pay attention to the design.

steps.headline: Come up with a theme and color scheme for your lantern.
steps.description:
If decorating a lantern sounds overwhelming and you don't know where to start, choose your holiday first, then find a theme and color scheme that goes with that holiday. This will come in handy when you have to find paint, lights, and decorations for your lantern. For example:
Black, purple, and orange are classic Halloween colors. If pumpkins and ghosts aren't your thing, try a Victorian or Gothic theme. Red and green are traditional Christmas colors, but you can also go with a winter wonderland theme. In this case, your color scheme might be silver, white, and blue.

steps.headline: Repaint the lantern if you want to change its color.
steps.description: Cover the edges of the glass panels with masking tape first. Next, use a wide, taklon paintbrush to apply acrylic craft paint to the lantern's frame. Let the paint dry, then apply a second coat if the first coat is too thin. Remove the tape, then let the paint dry. Keep the holiday you are celebrating in mind. Black is great for Halloween while red is perfect for Christmas.

steps.headline: Paint or decorate the glass panels if you want something fancier.
steps.description:
Here is where you can get really creative. You can etch or paint the glass, or even glue items to it. Because the glass panels in a lantern can be difficult to remove, you will need to decorate 1 side at a time. Here are some ideas to get you started:
Use stencils and a glass etching cream to create frosted designs. Create silhouettes with stencils and acrylic craft paint. Hot glue snowflake ornaments or silk fall leaves to the glass to create a more festive design. Paint designs with decoupage glue and sprinkle iridescent glitter over it for a sparkly effect.

steps.headline: Use battery-operated lights or candles in your lantern.
steps.description: Each 1 of these will give you a different effect. Pillar, votive, and tea light LED candles will give you the most traditional look. If you prefer something more magical looking, consider battery-operated string lights. You can get mini string lights that look like Christmas tree lights, or you can get tiny-bulbed fairy lights instead. String lights are a great option if you are filling your lantern to the top with a filler, such as pinecones or ornaments. You can use real candles, but only if you aren't adding any other decorations inside, and only if the lantern is made from metal--not wood. You can even use both, an LED pillar or votive light and fairy lights.

steps.headline: Wrap floral stems around the base of a candle for an elegant display.
steps.description: Set a pillar or votive LED candle into your lantern. Cut down some fake, floral greenery, then wrap it around the base of the candle. Add some other decorations, such as pinecones. For a Christmas lantern, try branches that have red berries on them. Add 2 to 3 mini pinecones. For an Easter lantern, try boxwood branches or pastel flowers. Add some fake, glittery Easter eggs or pompom chicks. For a more elegant display, add a strand of delicate fairy lights into the lantern, then hide the battery pack under the candle.

steps.headline: Fill the lantern all the way to the top with decorations as an alternative.
steps.description: Open up your lantern, then fill it all the way with items that represent your holiday. For a more elegant display, add battery-operated string lights. Hide the battery pack at the top or bottom of the lantern. Close the lantern, than stand it upright. For Christmas, try pinecones or ornaments. You can also use sprigs of fake pine or branches with red berries on them. For Halloween or Thanksgiving, try fall silk leaves or mini foam pumpkins. Add some plastic spiders if it is for Halloween. For Easter, use plastic Easter eggs. You can get brightly colored ones, glittery ones, or realistic ones.

steps.headline: Create a mini scene inside the lantern if you want to get creative.
steps.description: Add some felt to make grass or snow, then use figurines to make a scene. Light the lantern with mini fairy lights. The scene doesn't have to be related to Christmas or winter. Try a Halloween or Easter scene!

steps.headline: Add an ornate, ribbon topper if you really want something fancy.
steps.description: Tie the ribbon into a multi-looped floral bow. Decorate the ribbon with floral items that match your theme, such as sprigs of holly or evergreen. Secure the bow to the top of your lantern with wire or pipe cleaner. Use a wired ribbon that matches your theme and color scheme. Match the color of the wire or pipe cleaner to the color of the lantern. Make the bow the same size as the top of the lantern--or bigger for a fancier displace. This is a great alternative to decorating the inside of your lantern.

steps.headline: Use a stencil to cut simple shapes from a paper bag.
steps.description: Slide a piece of cardboard into a paper lunch bag. Trace a simple design by hand or with a stencil, then cut the shape out. Remove the cardboard, open up the bag, and fill it with 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) of rice, pebbles, or sand. Set an LED tea light into the paper bag. This works great for alternative Jack-o-Lanterns, but you can use other shapes for other holidays, such as flowers or snowflakes. Do not use a real candle for this. If you must use one, place it into a glass jar, and do not leave the lantern unattended.

steps.headline: Paint a mason jar with reverse stencils for a rustic look.
steps.description: Decorate a mason jar with 1 in (2.5 cm) circle stickers. Spray paint the jar, let the paint dry, then remove the stickers. Set battery-operated fairy lights or an LED tea light inside. You can use other shapes too, such as Christmas trees or stars. You can even make a Jack-o-Lantern! Add a rope handle to the jar, then decorate it with evergreen sprigs. For extra glow, paint your jar with two layers of spray paint. Use gold first, then a different color second.

steps.headline: Create a magical winter lantern by coating a jar with Epsom salts.
steps.description: Coat a mason jar with a decoupage glue, such as Mod Podge, then roll it in Epsom salts. Let the glue dry, then place an LED tea light inside it. Add some iridescent glitter into the Epsom salt for a hint of sparkle. If your jar is large, the glue may dry before you finish coating it. Use a sponge brush to apply the glue instead, one small section at a time.

steps.headline: Cover a mason jar with tissue paper, then paint black silhouettes on it.
steps.description: Tear tissue paper into smaller pieces. Paint a mason jar with decoupage glue (i.e. : Mod Podge), then apply the tissue paper. Coat the jar with another layer of glue, then wait for it to dry. Use stencils and black acrylic craft paint to add silhouettes onto the tissue paper. Once the paint dries, add a tea light inside it. Use colors that match the season, such as orange for Fall or blue for winter. Use shapes that match the holiday, such as a Jack-o-Lantern face for Halloween, or Santa and his sleigh for Christmas. You can use up to two layers of tissue paper. If you add too many, however, the light may not shine through.

steps.headline: Use a nail and hammer to punch holes into a tin can.
steps.description: Remove the label from a tin can, then fill it with water. Freeze it overnight, then use a hammer and nail to punch holes into the can to create a design; keep the holes ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) apart. Let the ice melt and dry, then add a tea light inside. Use a dry-erase marker to trace your design first. Wipe it clean with a dry cloth afterwards. Spray paint the can afterwards, if desired. For example, if you made a Jack-o-Lantern, paint it orange! Punch 2 holes near the top of the lantern, then loop wire through it so that you can hang it!

steps.headline: Make a magical ice lantern if you live in a cold area.
steps.description: Fill a large can with about 1/2 cup (120 mL) of water. Place a smaller can inside, then fill it with rocks until both rims are level. Freeze the lantern overnight, then remove the rocks. Pour hot water over the outside and inside of the cans to loosen them, then pull the ice lantern out. Set it outside, then place a tea light into it. Use pieces of tape to keep the smaller can centered. Add some sprigs of holly or pine to make the lantern more festive. This lantern only works in areas that receive freezing and below freezing temperatures. If the climate is too warm, the ice will melt!

steps.headline: Choose a sheet of construction  paper.
steps.description:
The size does not matter, but it needs to be rectangular. An 18 by 24 in (46 by 61 cm) sheet would work great, though. The color is also up to you. If you want to make a traditional Chinese lantern, red would work the best. You can also use a different color for a specific holiday. For example:
Halloween: Orange or black
Valentine's Day: Red or pink
St. Patrick's Day: Green

steps.headline: Cut a 1 in (2.5 cm) wide strip from the narrow side of your paper.
steps.description: Use a pencil and a ruler to draw a cutting line 1 inch (2.5 cm) away from 1 of the narrow edges. Cut along this line, then set the 1 in (2.5 cm) wide strip aside for later. This strip will eventually make the handle.

steps.headline: Fold the paper in half lengthwise or hot dog style.
steps.description: Bring the long edges together, then flatten the paper. Run your fingernail back and forth across the crease to make it nice and sharp. Fold the paper evenly. Make sure that the edges and corners match up.

steps.headline: Cut a fringe into the folded edge, stopping 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the top.
steps.description: Turn your paper so that the folded edge is facing you. Draw a horizontal line across the top of the paper, 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the top edge. Cut slits into the folded edge until they meet the line you drew. Do not cut past the line, however. Draw the line with a pencil. This way, you can erase it! Make the slits all the same distance apart--about 1 inch (2.5 cm). The first and last slit should be about 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the sides of the paper.

steps.headline: Roll the paper into a tube, then staple the seam.
steps.description: Unfold the paper first. Roll the paper into a tube, so that the fold is on the outside. Overlap the narrow ends by 1 inch (2.5 cm), then staple them along the top and the bottom. The folded should be sticking out, not in. If you squash the tube, the fringe should flare out like a flower. You can glue the tube together instead, but you will have to hold it with paper clips or clothespins until it dries.

steps.headline: Staple the 1 in (2.5 cm) wide strip to the top of the tube for the handle.
steps.description: Take your 1 in (2.5 cm) strip from before, and staple 1 end to the top of the tube. Bring the other end of the strip to the other side of the tube, and staple it in place as well. Make sure that both ends of the strip are stapled to the top of the tube. You can glue the strips in place. Hold them with paper clips or clothespins until the glue dries.

steps.headline: Add some tissue paper streamers to the bottom edge, if desired.
steps.description: Choose 2 to 3 colors of paper streamers. Cut them into 12 to 14 in (30 to 36 cm) long strips, then glue them to the inside-bottom edge of your handle. You can also use pieces of double-sided tape. How many strips you use depends on how big your lantern is. You need to use enough so that the entire bottom edge is lined with paper streamers. If you don't have paper streamers, cut 2 in (5.1 cm) wide strips from tissue paper instead. Match the color to the season. For example, for a 4th of July lantern, use red, white, and blue.

steps.headline: Decorate the lantern with stickers or rhinestones, if desired.
steps.description: Choose some stickers that match the theme of your lantern, then stick them onto the top or bottom edge. For a fancier lantern, use rhinestones instead. Self-adhesive rhinestones would work the best, but you can use regular rhinestones and tacky glue too. For example, if you are doing a Valentine's Day lantern, use heart-shaped stickers. If you are making a fancy New Year's Eve lantern, try gold or yellow rhinestones.

steps.headline: Finished.
